"SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSE." The Congress finds that the Brown v. Board of Education decision was significant in ending school segregation. The admission of the Little Rock Nine to Central High School was a prominent example of implementing the Brown decision and led to the integration of other segregated schools. Central High School, as a result of the Brown decision, was a prominent national example and catalyst for integrating previously segregated public schools in the US. In 1997, it celebrated its 70th anniversary and was recognized as the most beautiful high school building in America. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1977 and designated a national historic landmark by the Secretary of the Interior. Central High School was designated a national historic landmark in 1982 for its role in the civil rights movement. The school's inclusion in the National Park System will highlight its significance in desegregating Southern schools. The National Park System will recognize Central High School's role in desegregating Southern schools and interpret its significance for future generations. The purpose of this Act is to preserve and protect the school in Little Rock, Arkansas, and its contribution to the civil rights movement in the United States. Establishment of Central High School National Historic Site. The Little Rock Central High School national historic site is established as part of the National Park System in Arkansas. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the site. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the Little Rock Central High School historic site in accordance with relevant laws. The Little Rock School District retains authority over the school. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements. The Secretary of the Interior will administer the Little Rock Central High School historic site in accordance with relevant laws, while the Little Rock School District retains authority over the school. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with public and private agencies to further the purposes of the Act. Coordination of visitor interpretation of the historic site will be done in collaboration with the Little Rock School District and the Central High School Museum, Inc. The Secretary will prepare a general management plan for the historic site within 2 years. They will coordinate with the Little Rock School District to ensure educational use of Central High School is not disrupted. The Secretary will work with the Little Rock School District to develop a management plan for the historic site and ensure Central High School's educational activities are not affected. The Secretary is authorized to acquire lands within the site with consent from the owner, except for lands owned by the State of Arkansas or its subdivisions, which can only be acquired through donation or exchange. SEC. 3. DESEGREGATION IN PUBLIC EDUCATION THEME STUDY. The Secretary is required to prepare a national historic landmark theme study on the history of desegregation in public education within 2 years. The study will identify sites that commemorate key events in the movement for racial desegregation in public education. The study aims to identify sites, buildings, and landscapes that illustrate key events in the historical movement for racial desegregation in public education. The Secretary will then identify new national historic landmarks related to this theme and prepare a list of the most appropriate sites for designation. The theme study will also establish linkages between these sites and provide opportunities for education and research. The theme study will identify sites for national historic landmark designation related to desegregation in public education. It will establish linkages between these sites and the Central High School National Historic Site, as well as recommend opportunities for education and research collaborations with various entities. The theme study on desegregation in public education will recommend cooperative arrangements with various entities to preserve key historical sites. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with educational institutions, public history organizations, or civil rights organizations for the theme study. Coordination with the general management plan is also emphasized. The theme study on desegregation in public education will be prepared in coordination with the general management plan for the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site. Public history organizations and civil rights organizations will be involved to ensure scholarly standards are met. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Such sums as necessary to carry out this Act can be appropriated.
